comments.commentBody:
He is a horrible creature.
He is selfish and greedy and puts his self interests above those of the country and it's people. He is an opportunist who takes advantage of an uninformed electorate.
And those are his good points.
I'm sure that he would agree with Donald Trump when he says, "I love the poorly educated".
You are so right.  The anti-federal government get more money fromt eh Feds than they pay in Federal taxes. Here in California we get less money than we pay.  We are paying for the Red States.
In other words, we don't care what our constituents want. We are here to serve the one percent and corporations.

Note that Trump also lost Maryland, which is not surprising except that he was the first Republican in a long time to lose Anne Arundel county, typically a Republican stronghold due to the military presence there.

Yet again the debate retreats into ceaseless ad hominim attacks and name calling.

Where is the civility? Where is the respect for ideas not your own? Where is the open minded acceptance of other people's priorities? Where is the acknowledgement that protest may be met with counter protest and this is not only allowed it is good and proper?

All of these things are submerged beneath a morass of moral outrage, arrogance, and prejudice. Beneath a bone deep conviction that you are a good person. When this conviction is mixed with contempt for others, it destroys the social contract and allows you to justify any action. And thus are atrocities born.

Do not give in to the temptation to feel contempt for others. Do not give in to the warm feeling of moral superiority. You are fallible, as are we all. And thus we all become simply...people. Flawed people yes, but still people and therefore worthy of courtesy

With Walker one need to only follow the money.  Walker is funded not just by the Koch brothers but by another out-of-state party, the Uihleins, owners of U-Line.  He works for them and only them and what they want, they get.  Right now they want to own a state.  What else is there to buy when you've bought all the material goods you want?  Pay to play is alive and well in Wisconsin and Walker's sanctimonious opinion piece is nothing more than his donors' attempt to further their agenda of getting rid of environmental regulation and not pay taxes so they can do as they please to our state.
Like somehow, giving power to the states is some magical solution to all things. Instead, I think it is an answer for having nothing done by government in a lot of cases. Glenn
Please excuse the relative crudeness of my comment. This piece made me sick to my stomach.

Republicans should stand up to the tyranny, not of the protesters, but of Trump Administration that is set out to dismantle the U.S. Government and seems to be bent on prioritizing the needs of a foreign government over the needs of the American People.

Take power from the Federal Government and give it to the States except when it is a liberal issue, then impose national standards. In general regulations are bad and should be removed, but new regulations should be put in their place to impede anything that liberals support, no matter how benign or positive. Complain vociferously about liberal tactics, but then do the same or worse yourself. I could go on, but you get the gist.

Governor Walker's record of anti-union attacks speaks for itself when the issue of community organization is raised: he is hardly a source to be listened to or countenanced. He and his ilk have never had the public good at heart, and their self-serving agenda will ultimately be defeated by the citizens, whose rising clamor they are currently trying to forget and ignore.
The main reason for states rights and similar efforts to devolve government is that it reduces the cost of bribery.

I think that the American people have had just about enough of these rip off swamp creatures who are just out to fleece the American people.
Scott Walker sees his government position as a business opportunity and only cares about himself.
The level of corruption in our government is ludicrous.
People like Scott Walker would and should face criminal charges in a government that was truly of, by, and for the people.

A convenient ideological notion it is. As it's easier for cronies and local oligarchs to hold power regionally then nationally, particularly with a divide and conquer strategy in mind. Seize control of states to seize control of country. Additionally Mr. Walker asserts disingenously "Americans were given a choice in November: Where do you want your dollar going? To your local school or to Washington? Caring for the needy in your community or to Washington? Their clear answer in 2016 was “not Washington.” The American people's answer was quite clear; they overwhelmingly voted for Clinton and against the Republican agenda!

Though I don't agree with Mr. Walker, I respect his right to his views and he is the duly elected governor of Wisconsin and, therefore, is entitled to go about trying to implement them. It's the blind support that he, and the Republican party is giving to the crazy guy running our country that makes me wonder if the Republicans really have the interests of the nation in their hearts.
And of course, we know what that governor did to the University of Wisconsin.
Please do take the wrong Walker way. The Rs can indeed achieve a new all time low acceptance ratings to match the performance of the most unpopular governor in the USA. Please...
"Returning authority to the states" includes marijuana policy too? Let the States decide?

"Stand strong", "put-up or shut-up", "don't let the left shape the debate", and "return authority to the states".  Mr. Walker's anger and truculence are on full display and are not likely to have much impact beyond a those who are similarly angry and truculent.  Hopefully that is a small group.

What I don't understand is why the New York Times, a standard of excellence in journalism, would publish such a lame, intellectually underwhelming piece of conservative drivel. I am all for hearing from intelligent and honest conservatives; we need to be having a conversation with them. But this piece is a semi-dishonest waste of space in an otherwise fine newspaper.

Single-payer healthcare is the standard in the civilized world. Obama tried to take us out our of the wilderness of our backward anti-social medical care system. After a horrendous battle with the regressive Republicans he was able to make one step forward with the ACA. Union buster Walker wants to take us back to healthcare Middle Ages - let the poor and sick just die in the streets and let everyone else pay whatever the insurance companies can extort from them. Walker - the poster boy for 19th Century bare-knuckle capitalism.

Yes Scott, we have seen how well States Rights has worked in the America's
past.
It is amazing that, once again, a person must be reminded that 3 million more people voted for Hillary than for the other person.

Or -- which is what we are all worried about -- die from it.  This is not a sports match where our team lost!  The lives and prosperity of Americans and the future health of the world are what is at stake!
Except for the ones that receive far more in federal aid than they contribute.
